ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Auditory Neuropathy / Auditory Dyssynchrony (AN/AD)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Characterized by present OAEs and Cochlear Microphonics (indicating preserved outer hair cell function) with absent ABR neural waves and absent acoustic reflexes; severe difficulty in noise despite good detection thresholds.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear pathology (e.g., Vestibular Schwannoma)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Suggested by asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss and absent reflexes, though MRI (performed by neurologist) was normal.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess hearing thresholds given complaint of difficulty hearing.
Evaluate speech recognition ability in quiet.
Investigate significant complaints of difficulty in noise despite hearing aids.
Site-of-lesion testing to check outer hair cell function given absent reflexes and noise difficulty.
Evaluate neural synchrony and integrity of the auditory nerve.
Verify benefit of FM system intervention.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation revealed bilateral asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss (right worse). Word recognition in quiet was good, but acoustic reflexes were unexpectedly absent bilaterally, raising suspicion for retrocochlear involvement or neural dyssynchrony.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral asymmetric SNHL; Left mild to moderate-severe, Right mild to severe (poorer by ~15 dB).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs consistent with PTA; WRS good (80% Right, 82% Left) in quiet.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes at all frequencies (500-4000 Hz).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Patient returned frustrated with hearing aids in noise. Testing revealed severe SNR loss, explaining why amplification alone was insufficient.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.result_summary: QuickSIN showed severe SNR loss (15.5 dB bilaterally).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Diagnostic site-of-lesion testing confirmed Auditory Neuropathy/Dyssynchrony. The presence of OAEs and Cochlear Microphonics indicated intact outer hair cells, while the absence of neural ABR waves confirmed neural dyssynchrony.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (TEOAE)
tests.result_summary: Present and robust bilaterally; absent contralateral suppression.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Absent neural waves (I, III, V); Cochlear Microphonics present and inverted on polarity reversal.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Verification of the FM system showed significant improvement in speech-in-noise performance compared to hearing aids alone.

tests.name: Speech-in-noise
tests.result_summary: QuickSIN with FM system: 5.5 dB SNR loss (Mild), a 10 dB improvement over HAs alone.

proposed_items: Referral to otologist/neurologist to rule out VIII nerve lesion
Hearing aid reprogramming (directional microphones, noise reduction)
counseling_actions: Explain the diagnosis of Auditory Dyssynchrony (volume vs. clarity issue)
Counsel on realistic expectations with hearing aids in noise
Educate on the use and maintenance of the FM system
Discuss communication strategies (positioning, reducing background noise)

red_flags_present: Absent acoustic reflexes with preserved outer hair cell function (suspicion of retrocochlear pathology)

escalation.rationale_short: To rule out space-occupying lesions or other retrocochlear pathology given the asymmetric hearing loss and absent reflexes.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing status, verify sustained benefit of FM system, and assess communication needs.

expected_outcome: Pure-tone audiometry (6-month follow-up): Hearing thresholds remained stable with no significant change.
Speech-in-noise (QuickSIN with FM): Average SNR loss was 6 dB (Mild SNR Loss), indicating sustained benefit from the FM system.
Patient reported satisfaction with the hearing aid and FM system combination and declined cochlear implantation at this time.
